title: Romans 8:28 Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of Romans 8:28 — 'all things work together for good' — and its surrounding context in Romans chapter 8.

questions.question: According to Romans 8:28 (KJV), 'And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his ___.'
questions.explanation: Romans 8:28 (KJV): 'And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.'

questions.question: According to Romans 8:28, who are the people for whom all things work together for good?
options: Them that love God, the called according to his purpose
Everyone in the world without exception
Those who follow the Law of Moses perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: Them that love God, the called according to his purpose
questions.explanation: Romans 8:28 specifies two descriptions of the same group: those who love God and those who are 'the called according to his purpose.' This promise is not universal — it is for believers.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 8:28 teaches that all things that happen to a believer are good in themselves.
questions.explanation: Romans 8:28 does NOT say all things ARE good — it says all things 'work together for good.' There is a critical difference. Suffering, persecution, and loss are not good in themselves, but God sovereignly works them together toward a good outcome for those who love Him.

questions.question: What does Romans 8:1 declare about those who are 'in Christ Jesus'?
options: There is therefore now no condemnation
They are free from all physical sickness
They will receive earthly wealth and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: There is therefore now no condemnation
questions.explanation: Romans 8:1 (KJV): 'There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.' This opening verse sets the tone for the entire chapter.

questions.question: In the 'golden chain' of Romans 8:29-30, which of these is the correct order of God's work?
questions.explanation: Romans 8:29-30 presents a chain of divine actions: 'whom he did foreknow, he also did predestinate... moreover whom he did predestinate, them he also called: and whom he called, them he also justified: and whom he justified, them he also glorified.'

questions.question: According to Romans 8:29, God predestinated believers to be conformed to the image of whom?
questions.explanation: Romans 8:29 (KJV): 'For whom he did foreknow, he also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of his Son, that he might be the firstborn among many brethren.' God's ultimate purpose for believers is Christlikeness.

questions.question: What triumphant question does Paul ask in Romans 8:31?
options: If God be for us, who can be against us?
Who shall ascend into the hill of the LORD?
What must I do to be saved?
How shall we escape if we neglect so great salvation?
questions.correctAnswer: If God be for us, who can be against us?
questions.explanation: Romans 8:31 (KJV): 'What shall we then say to these things? If God be for us, who can be against us?' This rhetorical question assures believers that no enemy can ultimately prevail against those whom God defends.

questions.question: According to Romans 8:37, believers are described as what through Christ?
questions.explanation: Romans 8:37 (KJV): 'Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors through him that loved us.' The Greek word is hypernikao — we do not merely survive but overwhelmingly triumph through Christ.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 8:38-39, death, life, angels, principalities, and powers are all able to separate a believer from the love of God.
questions.explanation: Romans 8:38-39 (KJV): 'For I am persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers... shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.' Absolutely nothing can separate a believer from God's love.

questions.question: In Romans 8:18, what does Paul say about present sufferings compared to future glory?
options: They are not worthy to be compared with the glory to be revealed
They are equal in weight to the coming glory
They are a sign that God has abandoned us
They are punishment for past sins
questions.correctAnswer: They are not worthy to be compared with the glory to be revealed
questions.explanation: Romans 8:18 (KJV): 'For I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us.' Paul puts suffering in eternal perspective.

questions.question: According to Romans 8:26-27, what does the Spirit do for believers when they do not know how to pray?
options: The Spirit intercedes for us with groanings which cannot be uttered
The Spirit writes our prayers in a heavenly book
The Spirit sends angels to pray on our behalf
The Spirit removes our need to pray
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit intercedes for us with groanings which cannot be uttered
questions.explanation: Romans 8:26 (KJV): 'Likewise the Spirit also helpeth our infirmities: for we know not what we should pray for as we ought: but the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered.'

questions.question: True or False: The promise of Romans 8:28 means that Christians will never experience suffering or hardship.
questions.explanation: Romans 8:28 does not promise the absence of suffering. In fact, Romans 8:17 says we are 'joint-heirs with Christ; if so be that we suffer with him.' The promise is that God works all things — including suffering — together for the believer's ultimate good.

questions.question: What Old Testament figure said words similar to Romans 8:28 when he told his brothers, 'ye thought evil against me; but God meant it unto good'?
questions.explanation: In Genesis 50:20, Joseph told his brothers: 'But as for you, ye thought evil against me; but God meant it unto good, to bring to pass, as it is this day, to save much people alive.' This is a powerful Old Testament illustration of Romans 8:28.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Romans 8:31: 'What shall we then say to these things? If God be for us, who can be ___ us?'
questions.explanation: Romans 8:31 (KJV): 'What shall we then say to these things? If God be for us, who can be against us?' This verse is a triumphant declaration of the believer's security in God.

questions.question: According to Romans 8:32, since God 'spared not his own Son,' what else will He do for believers?
options: Remove all suffering from our lives
Make us sinless in this life
questions.explanation: Romans 8:32 (KJV): 'He that spared not his own Son, but delivered him up for us all, how shall he not with him also freely give us all things?' If God gave the greatest gift (His Son), He will certainly provide everything else we need.
